A ring R is called commutative if the multiplication is commutative.
The image of a function \( f: A 	o B \) is the set of all elements in \( B \) that have at least one corresponding element in \( A \) via the function \( f \).
Does the concept of a/an Commutative Ring need to be defined for a definition of a/an Image of Map to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation:
The concept of the Image of a Map is defined purely in terms of functions and sets. It involves identifying the set of all outputs in the codomain (set B) that are linked to at least one input in the domain (set A) through a given function f. This definition is general and applies to any function between any two sets, regardless of the nature of the elements in those sets.

On the other hand, a Commutative Ring is a specific algebraic structure where the multiplication operation is commutative. This concept is relevant in the context of algebraic structures and their properties, particularly in the study of rings and fields.

The definition of the Image of a Map does not rely on or require the elements of sets A or B to have any particular algebraic structure, such as that of a commutative ring. Therefore, the concept of a Commutative Ring is not necessary for the definition or understanding of the Image of a Map.
